Real-Time Edge Intelligence in the Making: A Collaborative Learning Framework via Federated Meta-Learning

Sen Lin, Guang Yang and Junshan Zhang This work was supported in part by NSF under Grant CPS-1739344, ARO under grant W911NF-16-1-0448, and the DTRA under Grant HDTRA1-13-1-0029. School of EECE, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287
{slin70, gyang57, junshan.zhang}@asu.edu
Abstract

Many IoT applications at the network edge demand intelligent decisions in a real-time manner. The edge device alone, however, often cannot achieve real-time edge intelligence due to its constrained computing resources and limited local data. To tackle these challenges, we propose a platform-aided collaborative learning framework where a model is first trained across a set of source edge nodes by a federated meta-learning approach, and then it is rapidly adapted to learn a new task at the target edge node, using a few samples only. Further, we investigate the convergence of the proposed federated meta-learning algorithm under mild conditions on node similarity and the adaptation performance at the target edge. To combat against the vulnerability of meta-learning algorithms to possible adversarial attacks, we further propose a robust version of the federated meta-learning algorithm based on distributionally robust optimization, and establish its convergence under mild conditions. Experiments on different datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed Federated Meta-Learning based framework.

I Introduction

Since most of IoT devices reside at the network edge, pushing the AI frontier to achieve real-time edge intelligence is highly nontrivial, due to the requirements in performance, cost and privacy. Clearly, the conventional wisdom of transporting the data bulks from the IoT devices to the cloud datacenters for analytics would not work well, simply because the requirements in terms of high bandwidth and low latency would be extremely demanding and stringent. As a result, it is anticipated that a high percentage of IoT data will be stored and processed locally. However, running AI applications directly on edge devices to process the IoT data locally, if not designed intelligently, would suffer from poor performance and energy inefficiency, simply because many AI applications typically require high computational power that greatly outweighs the capacity of resource- and energy-constrained IoT devices. To address the above challenges, edge computing has recently emerged, and the marriage of edge computing and AI has given rise to a new research area, namely ‘edge intelligence’ or ‘edge AI’ [1][2].

It is highly challenging for a single edge node alone to achieve real-time edge intelligence. A key observation is that learning tasks across edge nodes often share some similarity, which can be leveraged to tackle these challenges. With this insight, we propose a platform-aided collaborative learning framework where the model knowledge is learnt collaboratively by a federation of edge nodes, in a distributed manner, and then is transferred via the platform to the target edge node for fine-tuning with its local dataset. Then, the next key question to ask is “What knowledge should the federation of edge nodes learn and be transferred to the target edge node for achieving real-time edge intelligence?”

Federated learning has recently been developed for model training across multiple edge nodes, where a single global model is trained across all edge nodes in a distributed manner. It has been shown that limited performance is achieved when fine-tuning the global model for adaptation to a new (target) edge node with a small dataset [3]. Along a different line, federated multi-task learning [4] has been proposed to train different but related models for different nodes, aiming to deal with the model heterogeneity among edge nodes. In particular, every source edge node, which is also a target edge node, is able to learn a unique model through capitalizing the computational resource and data belonging to other nodes. This, however, inevitably requires intensive computation and communications and is time-consuming, and hence could not meet the latency requirement for real-time edge intelligence.

Building on the recent exciting advances in meta-learning [5][6], in this paper we propose a federated meta-learning approach to address the questions mentioned above. The underlying rationale behind meta-learning is to train the model’s initial parameters over many tasks, such that the pre-trained model can achieve maximal performance on a new task after quick adaptation using only a small amount of data corresponding to that new task. Thus inspired, we advocate a federated meta-learning approach where all source edge nodes collaboratively learn a global model initialization such that maximal performance can be obtained with the model parameters updated with only a few data samples at the target edge node, thereby achieving real-time edge intelligence.

Different from meta-learning which requires the knowledge of the task distribution [6], the federated meta-learning proposed in this work removes this assumption, by making use of the fact that different edge nodes often have distinct local models while sharing some similarity, and it can automate the process of task construction because each edge node is continuously making intelligent decisions. Further, the federated meta-learning eliminates the need of centralized computation and thus offers the flexibility to strike a good balance between the communication cost and local computation cost (e.g., via controlling the number of local update steps).

The main contributions in this paper can be summarized as follows.

  • •

    We propose a platform-aided collaborative learning framework where a model is first trained by a federated meta-learning approach across multiple edge nodes, and then is transferred via the platform to the target edge node such that rapid adaptation can be achieved with the model updated (e.g., through one gradient step) with small local datasets, in order to achieve real-time edge intelligence. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to apply meta-learning to obtain real-time edge intelligence in a distributed manner.

  • •

    We study the convergence behavior of the federated meta-learning algorithm and examine the adaptation performance of the fine-tuned model at the target edge node. In particular, we are the first to investigate the impact of the node similarity and the number of local update steps on the convergence subject to communication and computation cost constraints. To establish the convergence, we impose bounds on the variations of the gradients and Hessians of local loss functions (with respect to the hyper-parameter) across edge nodes, thereby removing the assumption in meta-learning that requires all tasks follow a (known) distribution.

  • •

    To combat against the possible vulnerability of meta-learning algorithms, we propose a robust version of federated meta-learning, building on recent advances in distributionally robust optimization (DRO). We further show that the proposed algorithm still converges under mild technical conditions. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to exploit DRO for improving the robustness of meta-learning algorithms.

  • •

    We evaluate the performance of the proposed collaborative learning framework using different datasets, which corroborates the effectiveness of federated meta-learning and showcases the robustness of the DRO-based robust federated meta-learning.

II Related Work

The concept of meta-learning is not new, but the recent advances through gradient-based optimization bring it into the light again as a promising solution for fast learning. In particular, Finn et al. [6] propose one gradient-based algorithm called MAML, which directly optimizes the learning performance with respect to an initialization of the model such that even one-step gradient descent from that initialization can still produce good results on a new task. To circumvent the need of the second derivatives in MAML, Nichol et al. [7] propose a first-order method named Reptile, which is similar to joint training but surprisingly works well as a meta-learning algorithm. A similar meta-learning framework is studied by Chen et al. [8] for recommendation systems through assigning one task to every user, which nevertheless does not consider any system modeling in federated learning.

To the best of our knowledge, we are among the first to establish the convergence of (federated) meta-learning. During the preparation of this work, the preprint of one concurrent work [9] about convergence analysis of meta-learning algorithms became available online. It is worth noting that [9] studies the convergence of centralized MAML algorithms for non-convex functions, whereas this paper focuses on the convergence and adaptation performance of the federated meta-learning algorithm with node similarity to achieve real-time edge intelligence in a federated setting, where multiple local update steps are allowed to balance the trade-off between the communication cost and local computation cost.

The susceptibility of meta-learning algorithms such as MAML to adversarial attacks is first investigated in [10]. And recently [11] also demonstrates the significant performance degradation of MAML with adversarial samples. To make meta-learning more robust, [11] proposes a meta-learning algorithm called ADML which exploits both clean and adversarial samples to push the inner gradient update to arm-wrestle with the meta-update. Unfortunately, this type of approaches are generally intractable. The DRO-based robust federated meta-learning algorithm proposed in this work is not only computationally tractable, but also resistant to more general perturbations, e.g., out-of-distribution samples. In addition, the trade-off between robustness and accuracy can be fine-tuned by the size of the distributional uncertainty set.

Federated learning is first proposed by Mcmahan et al. [12] which performs a variable number of local updates on a subset of devices to enable flexible and efficient communication patterns but without any theoretical convergence guarantee. Based on this, Wang et al. [13] analyze the convergence with fixed number of local updates for non-independent and identically distributed (i.i.d) data distributions across devices, and introduce a control algorithm to dynamically adapt the frequency of global aggregation to minimize the loss under fixed resource constraints. Departing from the need of manually tuning the number of local updates, Sahu et al. [14] propose a more generalized algorithm, so called FedProx, to tackle the statistical heterogeneity inherent in federated learning and characterize the convergence behaviour for non-convex loss functions. Notwithstanding, federated learning is not designed for fast learning with small datasets. In particular, federated learning intends to find a global model that fits the data as accurately as possible for all participating nodes, wheras federated meta-learning learns a model initialization, from which fast adaptation from even small datasets can still reach good performance, and also keeps the node heterogeneity in the sense that different models would be learnt for different nodes after quick adaptation from the global model initialization.

Both meta-learning and multi-task learning [15][16][4] aim to improve the learning performance by leveraging other related tasks. However, meta-learning focuses on the fast learning ability with small sample sizes and the performance improvement at the target (learning at the source is irrelevant), whereas multi-task learning aims to learn both the source and target tasks simultaneously and accurately. Besides, the model initialization learned by meta-learning can be fine-tuned with good performance on various target tasks using minimal data points, while multi-task learning may favor tasks with significantly larger amount of samples than others.

III Federated Meta-Learning for Achieving Real-Time Edge Intelligence

As illustrated in Figure 1, we consider a platform-aided architecture where a set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} of source edge nodes (each with a task) join force for federated meta-learning, and the learned model would be transferred from the platform to a target edge node t𝑡t (not in 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}), for rapid adaptation based on its local data. The primary objective of the proposed federated meta-learning is to train a meta-model that can quickly adapt to the task at the target edge node to achieve real-time edge intelligence, using only a few local data points. To accomplish this, the meta-model is trained during a meta-learning phase across the source edge nodes in a distributed manner.

III-A Problem Formulation

Specifically, we assume that the tasks across edge nodes follow a meta-model, represented by a parametrized function f𝜽subscript𝑓𝜽f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} with parameters 𝜽∈ℝd𝜽superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. For source edge node i∈𝒮𝑖𝒮i\in\mathcal{S}, let Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} denote its local dataset {(𝐱i1,𝐲i1),…,(𝐱ij,𝐲ij),…,(𝐱i|Di|,𝐲i|Di|)}superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑖1…superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑖𝑗…superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖\{(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{1},\mathbf{y}_{i}^{1}),...,(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{j},\mathbf{y}_{i}^{j}),...,(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{|D_{i}|},\mathbf{y}_{i}^{|D_{i}|})\}, where |Di|subscript𝐷𝑖|D_{i}| is the dataset size and (𝐱j,𝐲j)∈𝒳×𝒴superscript𝐱𝑗superscript𝐲𝑗𝒳𝒴(\mathbf{x}^{j},\mathbf{y}^{j})\in\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y} is a sample point with 𝐱jsuperscript𝐱𝑗\mathbf{x}^{j} being the input and 𝐲jsuperscript𝐲𝑗\mathbf{y}^{j} the output. We further assume that (𝐱ij,𝐲ij)superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑖𝑗(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{j},\mathbf{y}_{i}^{j}) follows an unknown distribution Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}. Denote the loss function by l​(𝜽,(𝐱j,𝐲j)):𝒳×𝒴→ℝ:𝑙𝜽superscript𝐱𝑗superscript𝐲𝑗→𝒳𝒴ℝl(\boldsymbol{\theta},(\mathbf{x}^{j},\mathbf{y}^{j})):\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}. L​(𝜽,Di)≜1|Di|​∑(𝐱ij,𝐲ij)∈Dil​(𝜽,(𝐱ij,𝐲ij)),≜𝐿𝜽subscript𝐷𝑖1subscript𝐷𝑖subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑖𝑗subscript𝐷𝑖𝑙𝜽superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑖𝑗L(\boldsymbol{\theta},D_{i})\triangleq\frac{1}{|D_{i}|}\sum_{(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{j},\mathbf{y}_{i}^{j})\in D_{i}}l(\boldsymbol{\theta},(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{j},\mathbf{y}_{i}^{j})),\vspace{-0.1cm} (1)

which we write as Li​(𝜽)subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) for brevity. Moreover, we use Lw​(𝜽)subscript𝐿𝑤𝜽L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) to denote the overall loss function across all edge nodes in 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}:

Lw​(𝜽)≜∑i∈𝒮ωi​Li​(𝜽),≜subscript𝐿𝑤𝜽subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝜔𝑖subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\triangleq\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\omega_{i}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),\vspace{-0.2cm} (2)

where ωi=|Di|∑i∈𝒮|Di|subscript𝜔𝑖subscript𝐷𝑖subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝐷𝑖\omega_{i}=\frac{|D_{i}|}{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}|D_{i}|} and the weight ωisubscript𝜔𝑖\omega_{i} of each edge node depends on its own local data size.

In the same spirit as MAML, we consider that the target edge node t𝑡t has K𝐾K data samples, i.e., |Dt|=Ksubscript𝐷𝑡𝐾|D_{t}|=K. For each source edge node i∈𝒮𝑖𝒮i\in\mathcal{S}, Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i} is divided into two disjoint sets, the training set Dit​r​a​i​nsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛D_{i}^{train} and the testing set Dit​e​s​tsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡D_{i}^{test}, where |Dit​r​a​i​n|=Ksuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛𝐾|D_{i}^{train}|=K (assuming |Di|>Ksubscript𝐷𝑖𝐾|D_{i}|>K for all i∈𝒮𝑖𝒮i\in\mathcal{S}). Given the model parameter 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}, the edge node i𝑖i first updates 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} using one step gradient descent based on Dit​r​a​i​nsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛D_{i}^{train}:

ϕi​(𝜽)=𝜽−α​∇𝜽L​(𝜽,Dit​r​a​i​n),subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖𝜽𝜽𝛼subscript∇𝜽𝐿𝜽superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\boldsymbol{\theta}-\alpha\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}L(\boldsymbol{\theta},D_{i}^{train}),\vspace{-0.1cm} (3)

with α𝛼\alpha being the learning rate, and then evaluates the loss L​(ϕi,Dit​e​s​t)𝐿subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡L(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i},D_{i}^{test}) for the updated model parameter ϕisubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i} based on Dit​e​s​tsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡D_{i}^{test}. It follows that the overall objective of the federated meta-learning is given by {mini} θ∑_i∈Sω_i L(ϕ_i(θ),D_i^test). Intuitively, by considering how the test error on local testing datasets changes with respect to the updated model parameters, we aim to obtain a model initialization such that small changes in the model parameters, i.e., altering in the direction of the loss gradient, would lead to substantial performance improvements for any task across the edge nodes.

Departing from MAML which assumes that a distribution over tasks is given, we do not require such an assumption here. Instead, we will quantify the node similarity in terms of the variations of the gradients and Hessians of local loss functions with respect to the hyper-parameter. Worth noting is that without knowing the data, the platform cannot directly solve the problem (3).

III-B Federated Meta-Learning (FedML)

Motivated by federated learning, we propose to solve the meta-learning objective (3) in a distributed manner, in the sense that each node locally updates the model parameter 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} based on its own dataset and transmits the updated value to the platform for a global aggregation. To better utilize the local computing resource of edge nodes and reduce the communication cost between the platform and edge nodes which is often a significant bottleneck in wireless networks, each edge node is allowed to locally update 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} for T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} steps before uploading the results to the platform.

Federated Meta-Training across Source Nodes: More specifically, the platform transfers an initialized 𝜽0superscript𝜽0\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0} to all nodes in 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} at time t=0𝑡0t=0. As outlined in Algorithm 1, there are two major steps:

  • •

    Local Update: For t≠n​T0𝑡𝑛subscript𝑇0t\neq nT_{0} where n∈ℕ+𝑛superscriptℕn\in\mathbb{N}^{+}, each node i∈𝒮𝑖𝒮i\in\mathcal{S} first updates 𝜽itsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{t} using the training dataset Dit​r​a​i​nsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛D_{i}^{train} based on (3) and then locally updates 𝜽itsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{t} again through evaluating ϕitsuperscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖𝑡\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}^{t} on the testing dataset Dit​e​s​tsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡D_{i}^{test}:

    𝜽it+1=𝜽it−β​∇𝜽L​(ϕit,Dit​e​s​t),superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑡𝛽subscript∇𝜽𝐿superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{t+1}=\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{t}-\beta\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}L(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}^{t},D_{i}^{test}), (4)

    where β𝛽\beta is the meta learning rate and 𝜽it+1superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{t+1} will be used as the starting point for the next iteration at node i𝑖i.

  • •

    Global Aggregation: For t=n​T0𝑡𝑛subscript𝑇0t=nT_{0}, each node also needs to transmit the updated 𝜽it+1superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{t+1} to the platform. The platform then performs a global aggregation to achieve 𝜽t+1superscript𝜽𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t+1}:

    𝜽t+1=∑i∈𝒮ωi​𝜽it+1,superscript𝜽𝑡1subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝜔𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t+1}=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\omega_{i}\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{t+1}, (5)

    and sends 𝜽t+1superscript𝜽𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t+1} back to all edge nodes for the next iteration.

The details are summarized in Algorithm 1.

Fast Adaptation towards Real-time Edge Intelligence at Target Node: Given the model parameter 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} from the platform, the target edge node t𝑡t can quickly adapt the model based on its local dataset Dtsubscript𝐷𝑡D_{t} and obtain a new model parameter ϕtsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑡\boldsymbol{\phi}_{t} through one step gradient descent:

ϕ𝒕=𝜽−α​∇𝜽L​(𝜽,Dt).subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝒕𝜽𝛼subscript∇𝜽𝐿𝜽subscript𝐷𝑡\boldsymbol{\phi_{t}}=\boldsymbol{\theta}-\alpha\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}L(\boldsymbol{\theta},D_{t}). (6)

In a nutshell, instead of training each source edge node to learn a global model as in federated learning, the source nodes join force to learn how to learn quickly with only a few data samples in a distributed manner, i.e., learn 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} such that just one step gradient descent from 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} can bring up a new model suitable for a specific target node. This greatly improves the fast learning capability at the edge with the collaboration among edge nodes.

IV Performance Analysis

In this section, we seek to answer the following two key questions : (1) What is the convergence performance of the proposed federated meta-learning algorithm? (2) Can the fast adaptation at the target node achieve good performance?

IV-A Convergence Analysis

For ease of exposition, we define function Gi​(𝜽)≜Li​(ϕi​(𝜽))≜subscript𝐺𝑖𝜽subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖𝜽G_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\triangleq L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})) and G​(𝜽)≜∑i∈𝒮ωi​Gi​(𝜽)≜𝐺𝜽subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝜔𝑖subscript𝐺𝑖𝜽G(\boldsymbol{\theta})\triangleq\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\omega_{i}G_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) such that problem (3) can be written as: {mini} θG(θ). For convenience, we assume T=N​T0𝑇𝑁subscript𝑇0T=NT_{0} and make the following assumptions to the loss function for all i∈𝒮𝑖𝒮i\in\mathcal{S}:

Assumption 1.

Each Li​(𝛉)subscript𝐿𝑖𝛉L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex, i.e., for all 𝛉𝛉\boldsymbol{\theta}, 𝛉′∈ℝdsuperscript𝛉′superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

⟨∇Li​(𝜽)−∇Li​(𝜽′),𝜽−𝜽′⟩≥μ​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖2.∇subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑖superscript𝜽′𝜽superscript𝜽′𝜇superscriptnorm𝜽superscript𝜽′2\langle\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}),\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\rangle\geq\mu\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|^{2}.
Assumption 2.

Each Li​(𝛉)subscript𝐿𝑖𝛉L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is H𝐻H-smooth, i.e., for all 𝛉𝛉\boldsymbol{\theta}, 𝛉′∈ℝdsuperscript𝛉′superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

‖∇Li​(𝜽)−∇Li​(𝜽′)‖≤H​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖,norm∇subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑖superscript𝜽′𝐻norm𝜽superscript𝜽′\|\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})\|\leq H\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|,

and there exist constant B𝐵B such that for all 𝛉∈ℝd𝛉superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}

‖∇Li​(𝜽)‖≤B.norm∇subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽𝐵\|\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|\leq B.
Assumption 3.

The Hessian of each Li​(𝛉)subscript𝐿𝑖𝛉L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is ρ𝜌\rho-Lipschitz, i.e., for all 𝛉𝛉\boldsymbol{\theta}, 𝛉′∈ℝdsuperscript𝛉′superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

‖∇2Li​(𝜽)−∇2Li​(𝜽′)‖≤ρ​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖.normsuperscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽superscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖superscript𝜽′𝜌norm𝜽superscript𝜽′\|\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})\|\leq\rho\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|.
Assumption 4.

There exists constants δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i} and σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i} such that for all 𝛉∈ℝd𝛉superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}

‖∇Li​(𝜽)−∇Lw​(𝜽)‖≤δi,norm∇subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑤𝜽subscript𝛿𝑖\displaystyle\|\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|\leq\delta_{i},
‖∇2Li​(𝜽)−∇2Lw​(𝜽)‖≤σi.normsuperscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽superscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑤𝜽subscript𝜎𝑖\displaystyle\|\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla^{2}L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|\leq\sigma_{i}.

Assumptions 1-2 are standard and hold in many machine learning applications, e.g., in logistic regression over a bounded domain and squared-SVM. Assumption 3 is concerned with the high-order smoothness of the local loss function at each edge node, which makes it possible to characterize the landscape of the local meta-learning objective function. Assumption 4 is imposed to capture the node similarity. Specifically, we impose the condition that the variations of the gradients and Hessians of local loss functions (with respect to the hyper-parameter) across edge nodes are upper bounded by some constant. Intuitively, a small (large) constant indicates that the tasks are more (less) similar, and this constant can be tuned over a wide range to obtain a general understanding. Further, for a task distribution with task gradients uniformly bounded above (as is standard), Assumption 4 follows directly because ‖∇Li​(𝜽)−∇Lw​(𝜽)‖norm∇subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑤𝜽\|\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\| (also Hessian) can be viewed as the distance between a typical realization and the sample average. In a nutshell, the task similarity assumption here is more general and realistic than the assumption in meta-learning that all tasks follow a (known) distribution. It is worth noting that these assumptions do not trivialize the meta-learning setting.

To characterize the convergence behavior of the federated meta-learning algorithm, we first examine the structural properties of the global meta-learning objective 𝐆​(𝜽)𝐆𝜽\mathbf{G}(\boldsymbol{\theta}). Next, we study the impact of the task similarity across different edge nodes on the convergence performance of the federated meta-learning, which is further complicated by multiple local updates at each node to reduce the communication overhead.

Convexity and Smoothness of the Federated Meta-Learning Objective Function: Based on Theorem 1 in [17], we first have the following result about the structural properties of function G​(𝜽)𝐺𝜽G(\boldsymbol{\theta}).

Lemma 1.

Suppose Assumptions 1-3 hold. When α≤min⁡{μ2​μ​H+ρ​B,1μ}𝛼𝜇2𝜇𝐻𝜌𝐵1𝜇\alpha\leq\min\{\frac{\mu}{2\mu H+\rho B},\frac{1}{\mu}\}, G​(𝛉)𝐺𝛉G(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is μ′superscript𝜇′\mu^{\prime}-strongly convex and H′superscript𝐻′H^{\prime}-smooth, where μ′=μ​(1−α​H)2−α​ρ​Bsuperscript𝜇′𝜇superscript1𝛼𝐻2𝛼𝜌𝐵\mu^{\prime}=\mu(1-\alpha H)^{2}-\alpha\rho B and H′=H​(1−α​μ)2+α​ρ​Bsuperscript𝐻′𝐻superscript1𝛼𝜇2𝛼𝜌𝐵H^{\prime}=H(1-\alpha\mu)^{2}+\alpha\rho B.

Lemma 1 indicates that when the learning rate α𝛼\alpha is relatively small, the meta-learning objective function G​(𝜽)𝐺𝜽G(\boldsymbol{\theta}) formed by the one-step gradient descent on local datasets is as well-behaved as the local loss function.

Bounded Dissimilarity across Local Learning tasks: Next, we characterizes the impact of the similarity across local learning tasks.

Theorem 1.

Suppose Assumptions 2 and 4 hold. Then there exists a constant C𝐶C such that

‖∇Gi​(𝜽)−∇G​(𝜽)‖≤δi+α​C​(H​δi+B​σi+τ),norm∇subscript𝐺𝑖𝜽∇𝐺𝜽subscript𝛿𝑖𝛼𝐶𝐻subscript𝛿𝑖𝐵subscript𝜎𝑖𝜏\|\nabla G_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla G(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|\leq\delta_{i}+\alpha C(H\delta_{i}+B\sigma_{i}+\tau),

where τ=∑i∈𝒮ωi​δi​σi𝜏subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝜔𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖\tau=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\omega_{i}\delta_{i}\sigma_{i}.

Given the bounded variance of gradients and Hessians of local loss functions, we can find upper bounds on the gradient variance of the local meta-learning objective functions, while still preserving the node heterogeneity. As a sanity check, if all the edge nodes have same data points, it follows that δi=σi=0subscript𝛿𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖0\delta_{i}=\sigma_{i}=0 for all i∈𝒮𝑖𝒮i\in\mathcal{S}. Consequently, all edge nodes have the same local learning objective.

Based on Lemma 1 and Theorem 1, we can have the following result about the convergence performance of the federated meta-learning algorithm.

Theorem 2.

Suppose that Assumptions 1-4 hold, and the learning rates α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta are chosen to satisfy that α≤min⁡{μ2​μ​H+ρ​B,1μ}𝛼𝜇2𝜇𝐻𝜌𝐵1𝜇\alpha\leq\min\{\frac{\mu}{2\mu H+\rho B},\frac{1}{\mu}\} and β<min⁡{12​μ′,2H′}𝛽12superscript𝜇′2superscript𝐻′\beta<\min\{\frac{1}{2\mu^{\prime}},\frac{2}{H^{\prime}}\}. Let δ=∑i∈𝒮ωi​δi𝛿subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝜔𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖\delta=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\omega_{i}\delta_{i} and σ=∑i∈𝒮ωi​σi𝜎subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝜔𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖\sigma=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\omega_{i}\sigma_{i}. Then

G​(𝜽T)−G​(𝜽⋆)≤ξT​[G​(𝜽0)−G​(𝜽⋆)]+B​(1−α​μ)1−ξT0​h​(T0),𝐺superscript𝜽𝑇𝐺superscript𝜽⋆superscript𝜉𝑇delimited-[]𝐺superscript𝜽0𝐺superscript𝜽⋆𝐵1𝛼𝜇1superscript𝜉subscript𝑇0ℎsubscript𝑇0G(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{T})-G(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star})\leq\xi^{T}[G(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0})-G(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star})]+\frac{B(1-\alpha\mu)}{1-\xi^{T_{0}}}h(T_{0}),

where ξ=1−2​β​μ′​(1−H′​β2)𝜉12𝛽superscript𝜇′1superscript𝐻′𝛽2\xi=1-2\beta\mu^{\prime}\left(1-\frac{H^{\prime}\beta}{2}\right), h​(x)≜α′β​H′​[(1+β​H′)x−1]−α′​x≜ℎ𝑥superscript𝛼′𝛽superscript𝐻′delimited-[]superscript1𝛽superscript𝐻′𝑥1superscript𝛼′𝑥h(x)\triangleq\frac{\alpha^{\prime}}{\beta H^{\prime}}[(1+\beta H^{\prime})^{x}-1]-\alpha^{\prime}x, α′=β​[δ+α​C​(H​δ+B​σ+τ)]superscript𝛼′𝛽delimited-[]𝛿𝛼𝐶𝐻𝛿𝐵𝜎𝜏\alpha^{\prime}=\beta[\delta+\alpha C(H\delta+B\sigma+\tau)].

Intuitively, the term B​(1−α​μ)1−ξT0​h​(T0)𝐵1𝛼𝜇1superscript𝜉subscript𝑇0ℎsubscript𝑇0\frac{B(1-\alpha\mu)}{1-\xi^{T_{0}}}h(T_{0}) captures the error introduced by both task dissimilarity and multiple local updates through the function h​(T0)ℎsubscript𝑇0h(T_{0}). Specifically, observe that h​(T0)ℎsubscript𝑇0h(T_{0}) increases with δ𝛿\delta and σ𝜎\sigma, which clearly indicates how the task similarity and the number of local update steps T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} impact the convergence performance, i.e., given a fixed duration T𝑇T the convergence error decreases with the task similarity while increasing with the number of local update steps when T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} is large. Correspondingly, the platform is able to balance between the platform-edge communication cost and the local computation cost via controlling the number of local update steps T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} per communication round, depending on the task similarity across the edge nodes.

Different from MAML, multiple local updates are allowed in Algorithm 1 to reduce the communication cost, which has nontrivial impact on the convergence behavior. As shown in Theorem 2, the convergence gap for federated meta-learning would be large if the number of local update steps T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} is large even if the tasks are very similar. When T0=1subscript𝑇01T_{0}=1, i.e., each edge node only updates the model locally for one iteration, the term B​(1−α​μ)1−ξT0​h​(T0)𝐵1𝛼𝜇1superscript𝜉subscript𝑇0ℎsubscript𝑇0\frac{B(1-\alpha\mu)}{1-\xi^{T_{0}}}h(T_{0}) disappears because h​(1)=0ℎ10h(1)=0. We have the following result for this case.

Corollary 1.

Suppose that Assumptions 1-4 hold, and the learning rates α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta are chosen to satisfy that α≤min⁡{μ2​μ​H+ρ​B,1μ}𝛼𝜇2𝜇𝐻𝜌𝐵1𝜇\alpha\leq\min\{\frac{\mu}{2\mu H+\rho B},\frac{1}{\mu}\} and β<min⁡{12​μ′,2H′}𝛽12superscript𝜇′2superscript𝐻′\beta<\min\{\frac{1}{2\mu^{\prime}},\frac{2}{H^{\prime}}\}. When T0=1subscript𝑇01T_{0}=1, G​(𝛉T)−G​(𝛉⋆)≤ξT​[G​(𝛉0)−G​(𝛉⋆)]𝐺superscript𝛉𝑇𝐺superscript𝛉⋆superscript𝜉𝑇delimited-[]𝐺superscript𝛉0𝐺superscript𝛉⋆G(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{T})-G(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star})\leq\xi^{T}[G(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0})-G(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star})].

IV-B Performance Evaluation of Fast Adaptation

The fast learning performance at the target edge node t𝑡t depends on not only its local sample size Dtsubscript𝐷𝑡D_{t} but also the similarity with the source edge nodes in the federated meta-learning. Denote 𝜽csubscript𝜽𝑐\boldsymbol{\theta}_{c} as the output of the federated meta-learning at the platform and 𝜽c⋆superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑐⋆\boldsymbol{\theta}_{c}^{\star} as the optimal meta-learning model. We assume that the convergence error ‖𝜽c−𝜽c⋆‖normsubscript𝜽𝑐superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑐⋆\|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{c}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{c}^{\star}\| of the federated meta-learning algorithm is upper bounded by ϵcsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑐\epsilon_{c}. For convenience, we further define Lt⋆​(𝜽)subscriptsuperscript𝐿⋆𝑡𝜽L^{\star}_{t}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) as the local average loss over the underlying data distribution Ptsubscript𝑃𝑡P_{t}:

Lt⋆​(𝜽)≜𝔼(𝐱tj,𝐲tj)∼Pt​l​(𝜽,(𝐱tj,𝐲tj)).≜subscriptsuperscript𝐿⋆𝑡𝜽subscript𝔼similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑡𝑗subscript𝑃𝑡𝑙𝜽superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑡𝑗L^{\star}_{t}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\triangleq\mathbb{E}_{(\mathbf{x}_{t}^{j},\mathbf{y}_{t}^{j})\sim P_{t}}l(\boldsymbol{\theta},(\mathbf{x}_{t}^{j},\mathbf{y}_{t}^{j})). (7)

Then, the empirical loss Lt​(𝜽)subscript𝐿𝑡𝜽L_{t}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is the sample average approximation of Lt⋆​(𝜽)subscriptsuperscript𝐿⋆𝑡𝜽L^{\star}_{t}(\boldsymbol{\theta}). Let ϕt=𝜽c−α​∇Lt​(𝜽c)subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑡subscript𝜽𝑐𝛼∇subscript𝐿𝑡subscript𝜽𝑐\boldsymbol{\phi}_{t}=\boldsymbol{\theta}_{c}-\alpha\nabla L_{t}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{c}) and ϕt⋆=arg⁡min⁡Lt⋆​(ϕ)=𝜽t⋆−α​∇Lt⋆​(𝜽t⋆)subscriptsuperscriptbold-italic-ϕ⋆𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝐿⋆𝑡bold-italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑡⋆𝛼∇subscriptsuperscript𝐿⋆𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑡⋆\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\star}_{t}=\arg\min L^{\star}_{t}(\boldsymbol{\phi})=\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}^{\star}-\alpha\nabla L^{\star}_{t}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}^{\star}). The following result characterizes the trade-off between the target-source similarity and local sample size.

Theorem 3.

Suppose l​(𝛉,(𝐱tj,𝐲tj))𝑙𝛉superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑡𝑗l(\boldsymbol{\theta},(\mathbf{x}_{t}^{j},\mathbf{y}_{t}^{j})) is H𝐻H-smooth with respect to 𝛉𝛉\boldsymbol{\theta} for all 𝛉∈ℝd𝛉superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and (𝐱tj,𝐲tj)∼Ptsimilar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑡𝑗subscript𝑃𝑡(\mathbf{x}_{t}^{j},\mathbf{y}_{t}^{j})\sim P_{t}. For any ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, there exist positive constants Ctsubscript𝐶𝑡C_{t} and η=η​(ϵ)𝜂𝜂italic-ϵ\eta=\eta(\epsilon) such that with probability at least 1−Ct​e−K​η1subscript𝐶𝑡superscript𝑒𝐾𝜂1-C_{t}e^{-K\eta} we can have

‖Lt⋆​(ϕt)−Lt⋆​(ϕt⋆)‖≤normsubscriptsuperscript𝐿⋆𝑡subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝐿⋆𝑡subscriptsuperscriptbold-italic-ϕ⋆𝑡absent\displaystyle\|L^{\star}_{t}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{t})-L^{\star}_{t}(\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\star}_{t})\|\leq α​H​ϵ+H​(1+α​H)​ϵc𝛼𝐻italic-ϵ𝐻1𝛼𝐻subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑐\displaystyle\alpha H\epsilon+H(1+\alpha H)\epsilon_{c}
+H​(1+α​H)​‖𝜽t⋆−𝜽c⋆‖.𝐻1𝛼𝐻normsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑡⋆superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑐⋆\displaystyle+H(1+\alpha H)\|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}^{\star}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{c}^{\star}\|.

Theorem 3 sheds light on how the task similarity and local sample size impact the learning performance at the target edge node t𝑡t. In particular, the performance gap between the optimal model and the model after fast adaptation is upper bounded by the surrogate difference, denoted by ‖𝜽t⋆−𝜽c⋆‖normsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑡⋆superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑐⋆\|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}^{\star}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{c}^{\star}\|, which serves as a guidance for the platform to determine how similar the source edge nodes in the federated meta-learning should be with the target node in order to achieve given learning performance via fast adaptation and hence edge intelligence at the target edge node.

V Robust Federated Meta-Learning (FedML)

It has been shown in [11] and [10] that meta-learning algorithms (e.g., MAML) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, leading to possible significant performance degradation of the locally fast adapted model at the target when facing perturbed data inputs. Thus motivated, we next devise a robust federated meta-learning algorithm and study the trade-off between robustness and accuracy therein (cf. [18]).

V-A Robust Federated Meta-Learning

To combat against the possible vulnerability of meta-learning algorithms, we propose to obtain a model initialization from which the model updated with local training data at the target not only is robust against data distributions that are distance π𝜋\pi away from the target data distribution Ptsubscript𝑃𝑡P_{t}, but also guarantees good performance when fed with the clean target data. Based on recent advances in distributionally robust optimization (DRO), this can be achieved by solving the following problem:

min𝜽⁡{Lt​(ϕt)+maxP:D​(P,Pt)≤π⁡𝔼P​[l​(ϕt,(𝐱,𝐲))]},subscript𝜽subscript𝐿𝑡subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑡subscript:𝑃𝐷𝑃subscript𝑃𝑡𝜋subscript𝔼𝑃delimited-[]𝑙subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑡𝐱𝐲\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left\{L_{t}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{t})+\max_{P:D(P,P_{t})\leq\pi}\mathbb{E}_{P}[l(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{t},(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}))]\right\}, (8)

where D​(P,Pt)𝐷𝑃subscript𝑃𝑡D(P,P_{t}) is a distance metric on the space of probability distributions.

To solve (8) with federated meta-learning, based on the general machine learning principle that train and test conditions must match, we can reformulate the federated meta-learning objective (3) as: {mini} θ∑_i∈Sω_i F_i(ϕ_i), \addConstraintF_i(ϕ_i)=L(ϕ_i,D_i^test)+max_P E_P[l(ϕ_i,(x_i,y_i))] \addConstraintϕ_i=θ-α∇_θL(θ,D_i^train) \addConstraintD(P,P_i)≤π, where a distributionally robust objective function similar with the target node is set for every source edge node i∈𝒮𝑖𝒮i\in\mathcal{S}.

V-B Wasserstein Distance based Robust Federated Meta-Learning

The choice of the distributional distance metric clearly affects both the richness of the uncertainty set and the tractability of problem (V-A). To enable distance measure between distributions with different support, we use Wasserstein distance as the distance metric on the space of probability distributions. More specifically, let the transportation cost c:(𝒳×𝒴)×(𝒳×𝒴)→ℝ+:𝑐→𝒳𝒴𝒳𝒴subscriptℝc:(\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y})\times(\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y})\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{+} be lower-semicontinuous and satisfy c​((𝐱,𝐲),(𝐱,𝐲))=0𝑐𝐱𝐲𝐱𝐲0c((\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}),(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}))=0, which quantifies the cost of transporting unit mass from (𝐱,𝐲)𝐱𝐲(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}) to (𝐱′,𝐲′)superscript𝐱′superscript𝐲′(\mathbf{x}^{\prime},\mathbf{y}^{\prime}). For any two probability measure P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q supported on 𝒳×𝒴𝒳𝒴\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y}, let Π​(P,Q)Π𝑃𝑄\Pi(P,Q) denote the set of all couplings (transport plans) between P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q, meaning measures W𝑊W with W​(A,𝒳×𝒴)=P​(A)𝑊𝐴𝒳𝒴𝑃𝐴W(A,\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y})=P(A) and W​(𝒳×𝒴,A)=Q​(A)𝑊𝒳𝒴𝐴𝑄𝐴W(\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y},A)=Q(A). The Wasserstein distance is then defined as

Dw​(P,Q)≜infW∈Π​(P,Q)𝔼W​[c​((𝐱,𝐲),(𝐱′,𝐲′))],≜subscript𝐷𝑤𝑃𝑄subscriptinfimum𝑊Π𝑃𝑄subscript𝔼𝑊delimited-[]𝑐𝐱𝐲superscript𝐱′superscript𝐲′D_{w}(P,Q)\triangleq\inf_{W\in\Pi(P,Q)}\mathbb{E}_{W}[c((\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}),(\mathbf{x}^{\prime},\mathbf{y}^{\prime}))], (9)

which represents the optimal transport cost, i.e., the lowest expected transport cost, that is achievable among all couplings between P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q.

Since the Wasserstein distance based optimization problem is computationally demanding for complex models, based on [19], we consider the following Lagrangian relaxation of the inner maximization problem of (V-A) with penalty parameter λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0:

maxP⁡{𝔼P​[l​(ϕi,(𝐱i,𝐲i))]−λ​Dw​(P,Pi)},subscript𝑃subscript𝔼𝑃delimited-[]𝑙subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖𝜆subscript𝐷𝑤𝑃subscript𝑃𝑖\max_{P}\{\mathbb{E}_{P}[l(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i},(\mathbf{x}_{i},\mathbf{y}_{i}))]-\lambda D_{w}(P,P_{i})\}, (10)

where λ𝜆\lambda is inversely proportional to π𝜋\pi. The duality result below in [20] based on Kantorovich’s duality, a widely used approach to solve the Wasserstein distance based DRO problem in optimal transport, provides us an efficient way to solve (10) through a robust surrogate loss:

Lemma 2.

Let l:ℝd×(𝒳×𝒴)→ℝ:𝑙→superscriptℝ𝑑𝒳𝒴ℝl:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times(\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y})\rightarrow\mathbb{R} and c:(𝒳×𝒴)×(𝒳×𝒴)→ℝ+:𝑐→𝒳𝒴𝒳𝒴subscriptℝc:(\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y})\times(\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y})\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{+} be continuous. Define the robust surrogate loss as lλ​(𝛉,(𝐱0,𝐲0))≜s​u​p𝐱∈𝒳​{l​(𝛉,(𝐱,𝐲0))−λ​c​((𝐱,𝐲0),(𝐱0,𝐲0))}≜subscript𝑙𝜆𝛉subscript𝐱0subscript𝐲0𝑠𝑢subscript𝑝𝐱𝒳𝑙𝛉𝐱subscript𝐲0𝜆𝑐𝐱subscript𝐲0subscript𝐱0subscript𝐲0l_{\lambda}(\boldsymbol{\theta},(\mathbf{x}_{0},\mathbf{y}_{0}))\triangleq sup_{\mathbf{x}\in\mathcal{X}}\{l(\boldsymbol{\theta},(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}_{0}))-\lambda c((\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}_{0}),(\mathbf{x}_{0},\mathbf{y}_{0}))\}. For any distribution Q𝑄Q and λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0, we have

maxP⁡{𝔼P​[l​(𝜽,(𝐱,𝐲))]−λ​Dw​(P,Q)}=𝔼Q​[lλ​(𝜽,(𝐱,𝐲))].subscript𝑃subscript𝔼𝑃delimited-[]𝑙𝜽𝐱𝐲𝜆subscript𝐷𝑤𝑃𝑄subscript𝔼𝑄delimited-[]subscript𝑙𝜆𝜽𝐱𝐲\max_{P}\{\mathbb{E}_{P}[l(\boldsymbol{\theta},(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}))]-\lambda D_{w}(P,Q)\}=\mathbb{E}_{Q}[l_{\lambda}(\boldsymbol{\theta},(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}))].

Lemma 2 divulges a worst-case joint probability measure W⋆superscript𝑊⋆W^{\star} corresponding to a transport plan that transports mass from 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} to the optimizer of the local optimization problem s​u​p𝐱∈𝒳​{l​(𝜽,(𝐱,𝐲0))−λ​c​((𝐱,𝐲0),(𝐱0,𝐲0))}𝑠𝑢subscript𝑝𝐱𝒳𝑙𝜽𝐱subscript𝐲0𝜆𝑐𝐱subscript𝐲0subscript𝐱0subscript𝐲0sup_{\mathbf{x}\in\mathcal{X}}\{l(\boldsymbol{\theta},(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}_{0}))-\lambda c((\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}_{0}),(\mathbf{x}_{0},\mathbf{y}_{0}))\}. Hence, we can replace (10) with the expected robust surrogate loss 𝔼Pi​[lλ​(ϕi,(𝐱i,𝐲i))]subscript𝔼subscript𝑃𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑙𝜆subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖\mathbb{E}_{P_{i}}[l_{\lambda}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i},(\mathbf{x}_{i},\mathbf{y}_{i}))]. Moreover, we typically replace Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} by the empirical distribution P^isubscript^𝑃𝑖\hat{P}_{i} because Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} is unknown.

In what follows, we focus on the following relaxed robust problem: {mini} θ∑_i∈Sω_i{L(ϕ_i,D_i^test)+E_^P_i[l_λ(ϕ_i,(x_i,y_i))]}, \addConstraintϕ_i=θ-α∇_θL(θ,D_i^train). Under suitable conditions, the robust surrogate loss lλ​(𝜽,(𝐱0,𝐲0))subscript𝑙𝜆𝜽subscript𝐱0subscript𝐲0l_{\lambda}(\boldsymbol{\theta},(\mathbf{x}_{0},\mathbf{y}_{0})) is strongly-concave for λ≥H𝐱𝜆subscript𝐻𝐱\lambda\geq H_{\mathbf{x}} [19], which indicates the computational benefits of relaxing the strict robustness requirements of (10). Therefore,

∇ϕilλ​(ϕi,(𝐱i,𝐲i))=∇ϕil​(ϕi,(𝐱⋆,𝐲i)),subscript∇subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝑙𝜆subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖subscript∇subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖𝑙subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖superscript𝐱⋆subscript𝐲𝑖\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}}l_{\lambda}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i},(\mathbf{x}_{i},\mathbf{y}_{i}))=\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}}l(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i},(\mathbf{x}^{\star},\mathbf{y}_{i})), (11)

where

𝐱⋆=arg⁡max𝐱∈𝒳⁡{l​(ϕi,(𝐱,𝐲i))−λ​c​((𝐱,𝐲i),(𝐱i,𝐲i))}.superscript𝐱⋆subscript𝐱𝒳𝑙subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖𝐱subscript𝐲𝑖𝜆𝑐𝐱subscript𝐲𝑖subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖\mathbf{x}^{\star}=\arg\max_{\mathbf{x}\in\mathcal{X}}\{l(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i},(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}_{i}))-\lambda c((\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}_{i}),(\mathbf{x}_{i},\mathbf{y}_{i}))\}. (12)

Here 𝐱⋆superscript𝐱⋆\mathbf{x}^{\star} can be regarded as an adversarial perturbation of 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i} under current model ϕisubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i} and efficiently approximated by gradient-ascent methods, revealing that problem (2) can be efficiently solved by gradient-based methods.

V-C Robust Meta-Training across Edge Nodes

To solve problem (2), similar to [21], we use an adversarial data generation process, i.e., approximately solving (12) with gradient ascent, to the federated meta-learning algorithm. More specifically, for every N0​T0subscript𝑁0subscript𝑇0N_{0}T_{0} iterations, each edge node i𝑖i constructs adversarial data samples using Tasubscript𝑇𝑎T_{a} steps gradient ascent and adds them to its own adversarial dataset Dia​d​vsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑎𝑑𝑣D_{i}^{adv}. Note that this sample construction procedure can only be repeated up to R𝑅R times considering the local computational resources constraints. For t≠n​T0𝑡𝑛subscript𝑇0t\neq nT_{0} (no global aggregation), each node i𝑖i first updates 𝜽itsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{t} using the training dataset:

ϕit=𝜽it−α​∇𝜽L​(𝜽it,Dit​r​a​i​n),superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑡𝛼subscript∇𝜽𝐿superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}^{t}=\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{t}-\alpha\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}L(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{t},D_{i}^{train}), (13)

then locally updates 𝜽itsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{t} again using both the testing dataset and the constructed adversarial dataset:

𝜽it+1=𝜽it−β​∇𝜽{L​(ϕit,Dit​e​s​t)+L​(ϕit,Dia​d​v)}.superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑡𝛽subscript∇𝜽𝐿superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝐿superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑎𝑑𝑣\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{t+1}=\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{t}-\beta\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\{L(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}^{t},D_{i}^{test})+L(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}^{t},D_{i}^{adv})\}. (14)

When t=n​T0𝑡𝑛subscript𝑇0t=nT_{0}, each node transmits the updated 𝜽it+1superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑖𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{t+1} for the global aggregation (5). The details are summarized in Algorithm 2.

V-D Convergence Analysis

Similar with Section 4.1, for clarity we rewrite problem (2) as the following: {mini} θ~G(θ), where G~​(𝜽)=∑i∈𝒮ωi​G~i​(𝜽)~𝐺𝜽subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝜔𝑖subscript~𝐺𝑖𝜽\tilde{G}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\omega_{i}\tilde{G}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) and G~i​(𝜽)=L​(ϕi​(𝜽),Dit​e​s​t)+𝔼Pi​[lλ​(ϕi​(𝜽),(𝐱i,𝐲i))]subscript~𝐺𝑖𝜽𝐿subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖𝜽superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡subscript𝔼subscript𝑃𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑙𝜆subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖𝜽subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖\tilde{G}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=L(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),D_{i}^{test})+\mathbb{E}_{P_{i}}[l_{\lambda}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),(\mathbf{x}_{i},\mathbf{y}_{i}))].

Assumption 5.

The function c𝑐c is continuous. And for every (𝐱0,𝐲0)∈𝒳×𝒴subscript𝐱0subscript𝐲0𝒳𝒴(\mathbf{x}_{0},\mathbf{y}_{0})\in\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y}, c​((𝐱,𝐲0),(𝐱0,𝐲0))𝑐𝐱subscript𝐲0subscript𝐱0subscript𝐲0c((\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}_{0}),(\mathbf{x}_{0},\mathbf{y}_{0})) is 1-strongly convex with respect to 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}.

Assumption 6.

The loss function l:ℝd×(𝒳×𝒴)→ℝ:𝑙→superscriptℝ𝑑𝒳𝒴ℝl:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times(\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y})\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex with respect to 𝛉𝛉\boldsymbol{\theta}.

Assumption 7.

The loss function l:ℝd×(𝒳×𝒴)→ℝ:𝑙→superscriptℝ𝑑𝒳𝒴ℝl:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times(\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y})\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is smooth with respect to both 𝛉𝛉\boldsymbol{\theta} and 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}, i.e.,

‖∇𝜽l​(𝜽,(𝐱,𝐲))−∇𝜽l​(𝜽′,(𝐱,𝐲))‖≤H​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖,normsubscript∇𝜽𝑙𝜽𝐱𝐲subscript∇𝜽𝑙superscript𝜽′𝐱𝐲𝐻norm𝜽superscript𝜽′\displaystyle\|\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}l(\boldsymbol{\theta},(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}))-\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}l(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime},(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}))\|\leq H\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|,
‖∇𝜽l​(𝜽,(𝐱,𝐲))−∇𝜽l​(𝜽,(𝐱′,𝐲))‖≤H𝜽​𝐱​‖𝐱−𝐱′‖,normsubscript∇𝜽𝑙𝜽𝐱𝐲subscript∇𝜽𝑙𝜽superscript𝐱′𝐲subscript𝐻𝜽𝐱norm𝐱superscript𝐱′\displaystyle\|\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}l(\boldsymbol{\theta},(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}))-\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}l(\boldsymbol{\theta},(\mathbf{x}^{\prime},\mathbf{y}))\|\leq H_{\boldsymbol{\theta}\mathbf{x}}\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\|,
‖∇𝐱l​(𝜽,(𝐱,𝐲))−∇𝐱l​(𝜽,(𝐱′,𝐲))‖≤H𝐱𝐱​‖𝐱−𝐱′‖,normsubscript∇𝐱𝑙𝜽𝐱𝐲subscript∇𝐱𝑙𝜽superscript𝐱′𝐲subscript𝐻𝐱𝐱norm𝐱superscript𝐱′\displaystyle\|\nabla_{\mathbf{x}}l(\boldsymbol{\theta},(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}))-\nabla_{\mathbf{x}}l(\boldsymbol{\theta},(\mathbf{x}^{\prime},\mathbf{y}))\|\leq H_{\mathbf{x}\mathbf{x}}\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\|,
‖∇𝐱l​(𝜽,(𝐱,𝐲))−∇𝐱l​(𝜽′,(𝐱,𝐲))‖≤H𝐱​𝜽​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖,normsubscript∇𝐱𝑙𝜽𝐱𝐲subscript∇𝐱𝑙superscript𝜽′𝐱𝐲subscript𝐻𝐱𝜽norm𝜽superscript𝜽′\displaystyle\|\nabla_{\mathbf{x}}l(\boldsymbol{\theta},(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}))-\nabla_{\mathbf{x}}l(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime},(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}))\|\leq H_{\mathbf{x}\boldsymbol{\theta}}\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|,\vspace{-0.2cm}

and there exists a constant B𝐵B such that ‖∇𝛉l​(𝛉,(𝐱,𝐲))‖≤Bnormsubscript∇𝛉𝑙𝛉𝐱𝐲𝐵\|\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}l(\boldsymbol{\theta},(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}))\|\leq B for all 𝛉∈ℝd𝛉superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and (𝐱,𝐲)∈𝒳×𝒴𝐱𝐲𝒳𝒴(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y})\in\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y}.

Note that Assumptions 6-7 can be stronger replacements of Assumptions 1-2, respectively. We characterize the robust federated meta-learning objective G~​(𝜽)~𝐺𝜽\tilde{G}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) below:

Theorem 4.

Suppose Assumptions 3 and 5-7 hold. When α≤min⁡{μ2​μ​H+ρ​B,1μ}𝛼𝜇2𝜇𝐻𝜌𝐵1𝜇\alpha\leq\min\{\frac{\mu}{2\mu H+\rho B},\frac{1}{\mu}\} and λ≥H𝐱𝐱+H𝛉​𝐱​H𝐱​𝛉μ𝜆subscript𝐻𝐱𝐱subscript𝐻𝛉𝐱subscript𝐻𝐱𝛉𝜇\lambda\geq H_{\mathbf{xx}}+\frac{H_{\boldsymbol{\theta}\mathbf{x}}H_{\mathbf{x}\boldsymbol{\theta}}}{\mu}, problem (V-D) has a unique minimizer.

Theorem 4 implies that when the learning rate α𝛼\alpha is sufficiently small and the Lagrangian penalty parameter λ𝜆\lambda is large enough, the relaxed robust meta-learning objective function G~​(𝜽)~𝐺𝜽\tilde{G}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is strongly convex and hence has a unique solution. Further, as outlined in Algorithm 2, through pre-training each edge node to learn to protect against adversarial perturbations on the testing dataset while securing the model accuracy on clean data with Algorithm 2, the learned model via meta-training automatically gains the ability to prevent future adversarial attacks without significantly sacrificing the learning accuracy with quick adaptation at the target edge node.

VI Experiments

In this section, we first introduce the experimental setup, and then evaluate the performance of FedML and Robust FedML. In particular, we investigate the impact of node similarity and number of local update step T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} on the convergence of federated meta-learning, and compare the fast adaptation performance of federated meta-learning (FedML) with the model learnt from federated learning (Fedavg) [12].

VI-A Experimental Setting

Synthetic data. To evaluate the impact of node similarity on the performance of convergence and fast adaptation, we follow a similar setup in [14] to generate synthetic data. Specifically, the synthetic sample (𝐱ij,𝐲ij)superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑖𝑗(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{j},\mathbf{y}_{i}^{j}) for each node i𝑖i is generated from the model 𝐲=a​r​g​m​a​x​(s​o​f​t​m​a​x​(𝐖𝐱+𝐛))𝐲𝑎𝑟𝑔𝑚𝑎𝑥𝑠𝑜𝑓𝑡𝑚𝑎𝑥𝐖𝐱𝐛\mathbf{y}=argmax(softmax(\mathbf{Wx+b})) where 𝐱∈ℝ60𝐱superscriptℝ60\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{60}, 𝐖∈ℝ10×60𝐖superscriptℝ1060\mathbf{W}\in\mathbb{R}^{10\times 60} and 𝐛∈ℝ10𝐛superscriptℝ10\mathbf{b}\in\mathbb{R}^{10}. Moreover, 𝐖i∼𝒩​(𝐮i,𝟏)similar-tosubscript𝐖𝑖𝒩subscript𝐮𝑖1\mathbf{W}_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{u}_{i},\mathbf{1}), 𝐛i∼𝒩​(𝐮i,𝟏)similar-tosubscript𝐛𝑖𝒩subscript𝐮𝑖1\mathbf{b}_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{u}_{i},\mathbf{1}), 𝐮i∼𝒩​(0,α~)similar-tosubscript𝐮𝑖𝒩0~𝛼\mathbf{u}_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\tilde{\alpha}); 𝐱ij∼𝒩​(𝐯i,Σ)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑗𝒩subscript𝐯𝑖Σ\mathbf{x}_{i}^{j}\sim\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{v}_{i},\Sigma) where the covariance matrix ΣΣ\Sigma is diagonal with Σk,k=k−1.2subscriptΣ𝑘𝑘superscript𝑘1.2\Sigma_{k,k}=k^{-1.2} and 𝐯i∼𝒩​(Bi,1)similar-tosubscript𝐯𝑖𝒩subscript𝐵𝑖1\mathbf{v}_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(B_{i},1), Bi∼N​(0,β~)similar-tosubscript𝐵𝑖𝑁0~𝛽B_{i}\sim N(0,\tilde{\beta}). Intuitively, α~~𝛼\tilde{\alpha} and β~~𝛽\tilde{\beta} control the local model similarity across all nodes, which can be changed to generate heterogeneous local datasets named Synthetic(α~~𝛼\tilde{\alpha}, β~~𝛽\tilde{\beta}). For all synthetic datasets, we consider 50 nodes in total and the number of samples on each node follows a power law. The objective is to learn the model parameters 𝐖𝐖\mathbf{W} and 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b} with the cross-entropy loss function.

Real data. We also explore two real datasets, MNIST [22], and Sentiment140 (Sent140) [23] used for text sentiment analysis on tweets. For MNIST, we sample part of data and distribute the data among 100 nodes such that every node has samples of only two digits and the number of samples per device follows a power law. We study a convex classification problem with MNIST using multinomial logistic regression. Next, we consider a more complicated classification problem on Sent140 by taking each twitter account as a node, where the model takes a sequence of 25 characters as input, embeds each of the character into a 300 dimensional space by looking up the pretrained 300D GloVe embedding [24], and outputs one character per training sample through a network with 3 hidden layers with sizes 256, 128, 64, each including batch normalization and ReLU nonlinearities, followed by a linear layer and softmax. The loss function is the cross-entropy error between the predicted and true class for all models.

Implementation. For each node, we divide the local dataset as a training set and a testing set. We select 80% nodes as the source nodes and evaluate the fast adaptation performance on the rest. When training with FedML, we vary the size of the training set, i.e., K𝐾K, for the one-step gradient update, whereas the entire dataset is used for training in Fedavg. During testing, the trained model is first updated with the training set of testing nodes, and then evaluated on their testing sets. For FedML, we set both the learning rate α𝛼\alpha and meta learning rate β𝛽\beta as 0.01 for synthetic data and MNIST, while α=0.01𝛼0.01\alpha=0.01 and β=0.3𝛽0.3\beta=0.3 for Sent140. Fedavg has the same learning rate with β𝛽\beta.

VI-B Evaluation of Federated Meta-Learning

Convergence behaviour. We evaluate the convergence error for (a) three different synthetic datasets with T0=10subscript𝑇010T_{0}=10 (b) the same dataset but different T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} with T=500𝑇500T=500. As illustrated in Figure 2, the experimental results corroborate Theorem 2 that the convergence error of FedML decreases with the node similarity but increases with T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} given a fixed algorithm duration T𝑇T. Moreover, the result in Sent140 (Figure 3(a)) shows that FedML also achieves good convergence performance in practical non-convex settings.

Fast adaptation performance. As shown in Figure 3(b), FedML achieves the best adaptation performance on Synthetic(0,0) where the nodes are the most similar. We also compare the fast adaptation performance between FedML and Fedavg on three different datasets, Synthetic(0.5,0.5), MNIST and Sent140. As shown in Figure 3(c)-3(e), the model learnt from FedML can achieve significantly better adaptation performance at the target nodes compared with that in Fedavg, and this performance gap increases when the target node has small local datasets. It can be seen that the model learnt in Fedavg turns to have overfitting issues when fine-tuned with a few data samples, whereas the meta-model in FedML improves with additional gradient steps without overfitting.

VI-C Evaluation of Robust Federated Meta-Learning

We compare the adaptation performance of FedML and Robust FedML on MNIST with T0=5subscript𝑇05T_{0}=5 during training. For adversarial perturbations only to feature vectors in supervised learning, we consider the transportation cost function as: c​((𝐱,𝐲),(𝐱′,𝐲′))=‖𝐱−𝐱′‖22+∞⋅𝟏​(𝐲−𝐲′)𝑐𝐱𝐲superscript𝐱′superscript𝐲′superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐱superscript𝐱′22⋅1𝐲superscript𝐲′c((\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}),(\mathbf{x}^{\prime},\mathbf{y}^{\prime}))=\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\|_{2}^{2}+\infty\cdot\mathbf{1}(\mathbf{y}-\mathbf{y}^{\prime}). The learning rate ν=1𝜈1\nu=1, R=2𝑅2R=2, N0=7subscript𝑁07N_{0}=7 and Ta=10subscript𝑇𝑎10T_{a}=10 for adversarial data generation. For testing at the target, we first update the meta-model with clean training data, and then evaluate the adaptation performance on clean test data and adversarial data, where the adversarial data is generated by using the Fast Gradient Sign Method [25] with parameter ξ𝜉\xi, respectively. Since the size of distributional uncertainty set controls the trade-off between robustness and accuracy, we compare the performance of Robust FedML with λ=0.1,1,10𝜆0.1110\lambda=0.1,1,10, where the smaller λ𝜆\lambda is, the more robustness Robust FedML provides.

Robustness-Accuracy tradeoff. As shown in Figure 4(a)-4(d), when λ𝜆\lambda decreases, Robust FedML has slightly worse performance on clean data and the performance on adversarial data is much better. Compared with the case where λ=10𝜆10\lambda=10, Robust FedML with λ=0.1𝜆0.1\lambda=0.1 significantly improves the robustness against adversarial data without sacrificing too much on the accuracy with clean data. Moreover, Robust FedML with smaller λ𝜆\lambda is more robust than FedML. Note that the uncertainty set is too small to positively affect the robustness when λ=10𝜆10\lambda=10.

Impact of ξ𝜉\xi. Clearly, both FedML and Robust FedML achieve better performance when facing smaller perturbation (smaller ξ𝜉\xi) of testing data. Figure 4(e) further indicates that the improvement of Robust FedML over FedML is higher with more perturbed data.

VII CONCLUSION

In this paper, we propose a platform-aided collaborative learning framework, where a model is first trained across a set of source edge nodes by a federated meta-learning approach, and then it is rapidly adapted to achieve real-time edge intelligence at the target edge node, using a few samples only. We investigate the convergence of FedML under mild conditions on node similarity , and study the adaptation performance to achieve edge intelligence at the target node. To combat against the vulnerability of meta-learning algorithms, we further propose a robust FedML algorithm based on DRO with convergence guarantee. Experimental results on various datasets corroborate the effectiveness of the proposed collaborative learning framework.

Appendix A Proof of Lemma 1

We first show that Gi​(𝜽)subscript𝐺𝑖𝜽G_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is μ′superscript𝜇′\mu^{\prime}-strongly convex and L′superscript𝐿′L^{\prime}-smooth. Specifically, observe that

‖∇Gi​(𝜽)−∇Gi​(𝜽′)‖norm∇subscript𝐺𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐺𝑖superscript𝜽′\displaystyle\|\nabla G_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla G_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})\|
=\displaystyle= ∥∇Li(ϕi)−α∇2Li(𝜽)∇Li(ϕi)−∇Li(ϕi′)\displaystyle\|\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i})-\alpha\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i})-\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\prime}_{i})
+α∇2Li(𝜽′)∇Li(ϕi′)∥\displaystyle+\alpha\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\prime}_{i})\|
=\displaystyle= ∥∇Li(ϕi)−α∇2Li(𝜽)∇Li(ϕi)+α∇2Li(𝜽′)∇Li(ϕi′)\displaystyle\|\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i})-\alpha\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i})+\alpha\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\prime}_{i})
−∇Li(ϕi′)+α∇2Li(𝜽)∇Li(ϕi′)−α∇2Li(𝜽)∇Li(ϕi′)∥\displaystyle-\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\prime}_{i})+\alpha\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\prime}_{i})-\alpha\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\prime}_{i})\|
=\displaystyle= ∥[I−α∇2Li(𝜽)][∇Li(ϕi)−∇Li(ϕi′)]\displaystyle\|[I-\alpha\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})][\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i})-\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\prime}_{i})]
−α∇Li(ϕi′)[∇2Li(𝜽)−∇2Li(𝜽′)]∥,\displaystyle-\alpha\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\prime}_{i})[\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})]\|, (15)

where ϕi=𝜽−α​∇Li​(𝜽)subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖𝜽𝛼∇subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}=\boldsymbol{\theta}-\alpha\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) and ϕi′=𝜽′−α​∇Li​(𝜽′)subscriptsuperscriptbold-italic-ϕ′𝑖superscript𝜽′𝛼∇subscript𝐿𝑖superscript𝜽′\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\prime}_{i}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}-\alpha\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}).

To establish the convexity, it suffices to show ‖∇Gi​(𝜽)−∇Gi​(𝜽′)‖≥μ′​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖norm∇subscript𝐺𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐺𝑖superscript𝜽′superscript𝜇′norm𝜽superscript𝜽′\|\nabla G_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla G_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})\|\geq\mu^{\prime}\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|. It can be seen from (A) that

‖∇Gi​(𝜽)−∇Gi​(𝜽′)‖norm∇subscript𝐺𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐺𝑖superscript𝜽′\displaystyle\|\nabla G_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla G_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})\|
≥\displaystyle\geq (1−α​H)​‖∇Li​(ϕi)−∇Li​(ϕi′)‖1𝛼𝐻norm∇subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖∇subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptsuperscriptbold-italic-ϕ′𝑖\displaystyle(1-\alpha H)\|\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i})-\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\prime}_{i})\|
−α​‖∇Li​(ϕi′)‖​‖∇2Li​(𝜽)−∇2Li​(𝜽′)‖𝛼norm∇subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptsuperscriptbold-italic-ϕ′𝑖normsuperscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽superscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖superscript𝜽′\displaystyle-\alpha\|\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\prime}_{i})\|\|\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})\|
≥\displaystyle\geq μ​(1−α​H)​‖ϕi−ϕi′‖−α​ρ​B​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖.𝜇1𝛼𝐻normsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖subscriptsuperscriptbold-italic-ϕ′𝑖𝛼𝜌𝐵norm𝜽superscript𝜽′\displaystyle\mu(1-\alpha H)\|\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}-\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\prime}_{i}\|-\alpha\rho B\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|. (16)

Since ∇ϕi=I−α​∇2Li​(𝜽)∇subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖𝐼𝛼superscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽\nabla\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}=I-\alpha\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), it follows from Assumption 1 and 2 that 1−α​H≤∇ϕi≤1−α​μ1𝛼𝐻∇subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖1𝛼𝜇1-\alpha H\leq\nabla\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}\leq 1-\alpha\mu, which indicates

(1−α​H)​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖≤‖ϕi−ϕi′‖≤(1−α​μ)​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖.1𝛼𝐻norm𝜽superscript𝜽′normsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖subscriptsuperscriptbold-italic-ϕ′𝑖1𝛼𝜇norm𝜽superscript𝜽′(1-\alpha H)\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|\leq\|\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}-\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\prime}_{i}\|\leq(1-\alpha\mu)\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|. (17)

Combining (A) and (17), we have

‖∇Gi​(𝜽)−∇Gi​(𝜽′)‖≥μ′​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖,norm∇subscript𝐺𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐺𝑖superscript𝜽′superscript𝜇′norm𝜽superscript𝜽′\|\nabla G_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla G_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})\|\geq\mu^{\prime}\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|,

where μ′=μ​(1−α​H)2−α​ρ​B>0superscript𝜇′𝜇superscript1𝛼𝐻2𝛼𝜌𝐵0\mu^{\prime}=\mu(1-\alpha H)^{2}-\alpha\rho B>0.

To establish the smoothness, it suffices to show ‖∇Gi​(𝜽)−∇Gi​(𝜽′)‖≤H′​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖norm∇subscript𝐺𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐺𝑖superscript𝜽′superscript𝐻′norm𝜽superscript𝜽′\|\nabla G_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla G_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})\|\leq H^{\prime}\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|. From (A) and (17), we have

‖∇Gi​(𝜽)−∇Gi​(𝜽′)‖norm∇subscript𝐺𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐺𝑖superscript𝜽′\displaystyle\|\nabla G_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla G_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})\|
≤\displaystyle\leq (1−α​μ)​‖∇Li​(ϕi)−∇Li​(ϕi′)‖1𝛼𝜇norm∇subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖∇subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptsuperscriptbold-italic-ϕ′𝑖\displaystyle(1-\alpha\mu)\|\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i})-\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\prime}_{i})\|
+α​‖∇Li​(ϕi′)‖​‖∇2Li​(𝜽)−∇2Li​(𝜽′)‖𝛼norm∇subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptsuperscriptbold-italic-ϕ′𝑖normsuperscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽superscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖superscript𝜽′\displaystyle+\alpha\|\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\prime}_{i})\|\|\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})\|
≤\displaystyle\leq H​(1−α​μ)​‖ϕi−ϕi′‖+α​ρ​B​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖𝐻1𝛼𝜇normsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖subscriptsuperscriptbold-italic-ϕ′𝑖𝛼𝜌𝐵norm𝜽superscript𝜽′\displaystyle H(1-\alpha\mu)\|\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}-\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\prime}_{i}\|+\alpha\rho B\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|
≤\displaystyle\leq H′​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖,superscript𝐻′norm𝜽superscript𝜽′\displaystyle H^{\prime}\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\|,

where H′=H​(1−α​μ)2+α​ρ​Bsuperscript𝐻′𝐻superscript1𝛼𝜇2𝛼𝜌𝐵H^{\prime}=H(1-\alpha\mu)^{2}+\alpha\rho B, thereby completing the proof of Lemma 1.

Appendix B Proof of Theorem 1

Observe that ∇Gi​(𝜽)=∇Li​(ϕi)−α​∇2Li​(𝜽)​∇Li​(ϕi)∇subscript𝐺𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖𝛼superscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖\nabla G_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i})-\alpha\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}) involves the product between Hessian matrix and gradient, which admits an upper bound outlined as follows:

‖∇2Li​(𝜽)​∇Li​(𝜽)−∑i∈𝒮ωi​∇2Li​(𝜽)​∇Li​(𝜽)‖normsuperscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝜔𝑖superscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽\displaystyle\|\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\omega_{i}\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|
=\displaystyle= ∥∇2Li(𝜽)∇Li(𝜽)−∇2Lw(𝜽)∇Lw(𝜽)\displaystyle\|\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla^{2}L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta})
+∇2Lw(𝜽)∇Lw(𝜽)−∑i∈𝒮ωi∇2Li(𝜽)∇Li(𝜽)∥\displaystyle+\nabla^{2}L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\omega_{i}\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|
≤\displaystyle\leq ‖∇2Li​(𝜽)​∇Li​(𝜽)−∇2Li​(𝜽)​∇Lw​(𝜽)‖normsuperscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽superscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑤𝜽\displaystyle\|\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|
+∥∇2Li(𝜽)∇Lw(𝜽)−∇2Lw(𝜽)∇Lw(𝜽∥\displaystyle+\|\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla^{2}L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta}\|
+‖∑i∈𝒮ωi​[(∇Li​(𝜽)−∇Lw​(𝜽))​(∇2Li​(𝜽)−∇2Lw​(𝜽))]‖normsubscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝜔𝑖delimited-[]∇subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑤𝜽superscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽superscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑤𝜽\displaystyle+\|\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\omega_{i}[(\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta}))(\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla^{2}L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta}))]\|
≤\displaystyle\leq ‖∇2Li​(𝜽)‖​‖∇Li​(𝜽)−∇Lw​(𝜽)‖normsuperscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽norm∇subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑤𝜽\displaystyle\|\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|\|\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|
+‖∇Lw​(𝜽)‖​‖∇2Li​(𝜽)−∇2Lw​(𝜽)‖norm∇subscript𝐿𝑤𝜽normsuperscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽superscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑤𝜽\displaystyle+\|\nabla L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|\|\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla^{2}L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|
+∑i∈𝒮ωi​‖∇Li​(𝜽)−∇Lw​(𝜽)‖​‖∇2Li​(𝜽)−∇2Lw​(𝜽)‖subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝜔𝑖norm∇subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑤𝜽normsuperscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽superscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑤𝜽\displaystyle+\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\omega_{i}\|\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|\|\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla^{2}L_{w}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|
≤\displaystyle\leq H​δi+B​σi+τ.𝐻subscript𝛿𝑖𝐵subscript𝜎𝑖𝜏\displaystyle H\delta_{i}+B\sigma_{i}+\tau. (18)

Next, it follows from Taylor’s Theorem that

∇Li​(ϕi)=∇Li​(𝜽)+∇2Li​(𝜽)​(ϕi−𝜽)+O​(‖ϕi−𝜽‖2).∇subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖∇subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽superscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖𝜽𝑂superscriptnormsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖𝜽2\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i})=\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})+\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}-\boldsymbol{\theta})+O(\|\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}-\boldsymbol{\theta}\|^{2}).

That is to say,

∇Li​(ϕi)=∇Li​(𝜽)−α​∇2Li​(𝜽)​∇Li​(𝜽)+O​(α2​B2).∇subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖∇subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽𝛼superscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽𝑂superscript𝛼2superscript𝐵2\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i})=\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\alpha\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})+O(\alpha^{2}B^{2}).

Therefore, we have

‖∇Gi​(𝜽)−∇G​(𝜽)‖norm∇subscript𝐺𝑖𝜽∇𝐺𝜽\displaystyle\|\nabla G_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla G(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|
=\displaystyle= ‖[I−α​∇2Li​(𝜽)]​∇Li​(ϕi)−∑i∈𝒮ωi​[I−α​∇2Li​(𝜽)]​∇Li​(ϕi)‖normdelimited-[]𝐼𝛼superscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝜔𝑖delimited-[]𝐼𝛼superscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑖subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖\displaystyle\|[I-\alpha\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})]\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i})-\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\omega_{i}[I-\alpha\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})]\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i})\|

−∑i∈𝒮ωi[I−α∇2Li(𝜽)][∇Li(ϕi)∇−Li(𝜽)+∇Li(𝜽)]∥\displaystyle-\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\omega_{i}[I-\alpha\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})][\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i})\nabla-L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})+\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})]\|

+2​α​∑i∈𝒮ωi​∇2Li​(𝜽)​∇Li​(𝜽)+O​(α2​B2)2𝛼subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝜔𝑖superscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽𝑂superscript𝛼2superscript𝐵2\displaystyle+2\alpha\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\omega_{i}\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})+O(\alpha^{2}B^{2})
+α2[∇2Li(𝜽)]2∇Li(𝜽)−α2∑i∈𝒮ωi[∇2Li(𝜽)]2∇Li(𝜽)∥\displaystyle+\alpha^{2}[\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})]^{2}\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\alpha^{2}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\omega_{i}[\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})]^{2}\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|

Along the same line as in finding an upper bound for ‖∇2Li​(𝜽)​∇Li​(𝜽)−∑i∈𝒮ωi​∇2Li​(𝜽)​∇Li​(𝜽)‖normsuperscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝜔𝑖superscript∇2subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽∇subscript𝐿𝑖𝜽\|\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\omega_{i}\nabla^{2}L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\nabla L_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|, we can find an upper bound on the last term of the above inequality with α2​(H​δi′+B​σi+τ′)superscript𝛼2𝐻subscriptsuperscript𝛿′𝑖𝐵subscript𝜎𝑖superscript𝜏′\alpha^{2}(H\delta^{\prime}_{i}+B\sigma_{i}+\tau^{\prime}) where δi′=H​δi+B​σi+τsubscriptsuperscript𝛿′𝑖𝐻subscript𝛿𝑖𝐵subscript𝜎𝑖𝜏\delta^{\prime}_{i}=H\delta_{i}+B\sigma_{i}+\tau and τ′=∑i∈𝒮ωi​δi′​σisuperscript𝜏′subscript𝑖𝒮subscript𝜔𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝛿′𝑖subscript𝜎𝑖\tau^{\prime}=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\omega_{i}\delta^{\prime}_{i}\sigma_{i}. We conclude that when α𝛼\alpha is suitably small, there exists a constant C𝐶C such that the right hand side of the above inequality is upper bounded by δi+α​C​(H​δi+B​σi+τ)subscript𝛿𝑖𝛼𝐶𝐻subscript𝛿𝑖𝐵subscript𝜎𝑖𝜏\delta_{i}+\alpha C(H\delta_{i}+B\sigma_{i}+\tau).

Appendix C Proof of Theorem 2

Appendix D Proof of Theorem 3
